prompt:
You are a cybersecurity expert specializing in incident classification.
Your task is to analyze security incidents and categorize them according to NIST guidelines.

NIST SECURITY INCIDENT CATEGORIES:

• CAT1: Account Compromise – Unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts
  Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft

• CAT2: Malware – Infection by malicious code
  Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus

• CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – Making systems unavailable
  Examples: volumetric DoS/DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood), HTTP/HTTPS attacks

• CAT4: Data Leak – Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data
  Examples: database theft, leaked credentials

• CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – Using technical flaws for attacks
  Examples: CVE exploitation, RCE, SQL injection, exposed services

• CAT6: Insider Abuse – Malicious actions by internal users
  Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage

• CAT7: Social Engineering – Deception to gain access or data
  Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud

• CAT8: Physical Incident – Impact due to unauthorized physical access
  Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in

• CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – Improper changes to systems or data
  Examples: defacement, record manipulation

• CAT10: Misuse of Resources – Unauthorized use for other purposes
  Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution

• CAT11: Third-Party Issues – Security failures by suppliers
  Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack

• CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – Unconfirmed attacks
  Examples: network scans, brute force attempts, blocked exploits

CLASSIFICATION EXAMPLES:

Example 1:
Incident: "Multiple failed SSH login attempts detected from external IP 192.168.1.100"
Category: CAT12
Explanation: Network scanning and brute force attempts represent intrusion attempts that were blocked/detected but not successful.

Example 2:
Incident: "Ransomware detected on workstation, files encrypted with .crypto extension"
Category: CAT2
Explanation: Clear malware infection with ransomware, representing malicious code that has successfully infected the system.

Example 3:
Incident: "Employee accessed and downloaded customer database without authorization"
Category: CAT6
Explanation: Internal user performing unauthorized actions, representing insider abuse of access privileges.

CC: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Assunto: Re: Compromised host used for an attack: [IP_ADDRESS_423202de2f] [~164 Mbps]

Hello,

CERT.br works as a coordinating team for incidents and abuses related
to Brazilian networks. We are listed in the "remarks" notes of the
Brazilian Whois Server output to receive copies of complaints, but we
are not the technical or abuse contact of any network.

We are forwarding your email to the proper contacts for this network
so they can handle this incident.

Original message was attached to this email.

Thank you for reporting this incident,
--
CERT.br/NIC.br
<[EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]>
[URL_ea4f5d47bf]

=======================================================================
----- Original message as text -----
From: [ORGANIZATION_1df86da352] DDoS notifier <[EMAIL_ADDRESS_92a6206f7f]>
To: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Subject: Compromised host used for an attack: [IP_ADDRESS_423202de2f] [~164 Mbps]
Date: Mon, 6 Feb 2023 23:54:03 -0800
Message-ID: <[EMAIL_ADDRESS_bfe4da8091]>

An IP address ([IP_ADDRESS_423202de2f]) under your control appears to have attacked one of our customers as part of a coordinated DDoS botnet. We manually reviewed the captures from this attack and do not believe that your IP address was spoofed, based on the limited number of distinct hosts attacking us, the identicality of many attacking IP addresses to ones we've seen in the past, and the non-random distribution of IP addresses.

It is possible that this host is one of the following, from the responses that others have sent us:

- A compromised router, such as a [ORGANIZATION_4fa360a1dd] that is running with WAN access enabled; a [ORGANIZATION_9954db40ae] which still allows a default admin username and password; a Netis, with a built-in internet-accessible backdoor ([URL_2764a7b048]); or one running an old AirOS version with a vulnerable and exposed administrative interface
- An [ORGANIZATION_8df3b93efb] device that is vulnerable to compromise (such as HTV), either directly through the default firmware or through a trojan downloaded app
- A compromised webhost, such as one running a vulnerable version of Drupal (for instance, using the vulnerability discussed at [URL_9346d9f602]), WordPress, phpMyAdmin, or zPanel
- A compromised DVR, such as a "Hikvision" brand device (ref: [URL_2002177763])
- A compromised IPMI device, such as one made by [ORGANIZATION_e8804ebb01] (possibly because it uses the default U/P of ADMIN/ADMIN or because its password was found through an exploit described at [URL_643058c363])
- A compromised Xerox-branded device
- Some other compromised standalone device
- A server with an insecure password that was brute-forced, such as through SSH or RDP
- A server running an improperly secured Hadoop installation
- A server running a pre-13.10.3 GitLab instance that is vulnerable to CVE-2021-22205
- A compromised [ORGANIZATION_c7bac46904] DNS server (through the July 2020 critical vulnerability)

The overall botnet attack was Nx10Gbps in size (with traffic from your host as well as some others) and caused significant packet loss for our clients due to external link saturation. It required an emergency null-route operation on our side to mitigate.

Attacks like this are usually made very short, intentionally, so that they are not as noticeable and slip past certain automatic mitigation systems. REQUIRED OUTPUT FORMAT:
Category: [CAT1-CAT12 or Unknown]
Explanation: [Detailed justification for the chosen category]

If the incident cannot be clearly classified, use:
Category: Unknown
Explanation: Insufficient information or incident doesn't match standard categories
response:
Okay, here's a classification of the incident based on the NIST guidelines, along with a detailed explanation:

**Category: CAT1 - Account Compromise**

**Explanation:**

The incident details a direct, unauthorized access attempt to a user account ("NFOservers.com DDoS notifier").  The user is actively attempting to connect to a server (IP_ADDRESS_423202de2f) under their control. This directly represents a breach of access privileges. The fact that the attacker is using a DDoS botnet ("Nx10Gbps") and causing network congestion suggests a malicious intent to disrupt services.  The incident is a direct violation of account security.

**Risk Level:** High – This is the most appropriate category.

**Further Considerations:**  The incident strongly suggests a potential brute-force or credential phishing attack. The attacker is actively probing for a valid username and password to gain further access.

---

**Category: CAT2 - Malware**

**Explanation:**

The incident describes a ransomware attack. The ransomware is specifically targeting workstations and includes the ".crypto" extension, which is a common indicator of ransomware.  The encryption of files is a key symptom, indicating malware infection. The attacker is attempting to encrypt and decrypt data, posing a threat to the victim's systems.

**Risk Level:** High - Ransomware is a significant threat, and the fact that the ransomware is specifically targeting workstations amplifies the risk.

**Further Considerations:** The incident's focus on a compromised host (IP_ADDRESS_423202de2f) is a critical piece of evidence.

---

**Category: CAT3 - Denial of Service (DoS/DDoS) Attack**

**Explanation:**

The description mentions "Ransomware detected on workstation, files encrypted with .crypto extension" and "Nx10Gbps in size (with traffic from your host as well as some others)". The combination of the ransomware infection, the botnet activity, and the network congestion all point toward a DoS/DDoS attack. The attacker is using a botnet to overwhelm the victim's network with traffic, causing service disruption.

**Risk Level:** Medium – While the attack is focused on a single host, the botnet component suggests a wider, coordinated attack.  The impact of a DDoS attack can be substantial, potentially disrupting critical services.

**Further Considerations:** The attacker’s action of sending the data to the target is a key indicator of malicious intent.

---

**Category: CAT4 - Data Leak**

**Explanation:**

The incident describes data exfiltration – the unauthorized disclosure of sensitive customer data. The mention of the customer database (customer database) and the use of encryption ( ".crypto" ) indicates the data was taken. The fact that the attacker is using a botnet is also relevant, as it could have been used to spread malware or spread data across multiple targets.

**Risk Level:** Medium – Data leakage is a significant risk, especially when it involves sensitive customer information.

**Further Considerations:** The specific nature of the stolen data (customer database) is important for investigation.

---

**Category: CAT5 - Vulnerability Exploitation**

**Explanation:**

The description highlights a compromised router and a vulnerability to exploitation. The attacker is attempting to use the compromised router as a gateway to the botnet.

**Risk Level:** Medium –  A compromised router is a critical vulnerability, and the attacker's use of it as a gateway demonstrates a successful exploitation of a known weakness.

**Further Considerations:** The vulnerability is likely a weak configuration setting, such as default admin password.

---

**Category: CAT6 - Insider Abuse**

**Explanation:**

The incident describes an internal user accessing and downloading data.  The user's actions are unauthorized and potentially damaging to the company.

**Risk Level:** Low – This is a standard incident, but the degree of access granted by the user is important for monitoring.

**Further Considerations:** The fact that the user is accessing a specific database highlights a targeted breach.

---

**Category: CAT7 - Social Engineering**

**Explanation:**

The incident describes a phishing email that impersonates a trusted source (CERT.br) and directs the user to a malicious link. The message is deliberately misleading and designed to deceive the target.

**Risk Level:** Medium – Social engineering attacks are a common method of gaining access to systems.

**Further Considerations:** The email's content is designed to be persuasive and leverage trust.

---

**Category: CAT8 - Physical Incident**

**Explanation:**

The incident details a laptop theft.

**Risk Level:** Low - While it doesn't directly relate to the incident, it's an external threat.

**Further Considerations:** The attack could be part of a larger botnet activity.

---

**Category: CAT9 - Unauthorized Modification**

**Explanation:**

The incident describes ransomware encryption and data exfiltration. The data being encrypted (possibly customer data) is a form of unauthorized modification.

**Risk Level:** Medium – Unauthorized modification of systems and data can have severe consequences.

**Further Considerations:** The ransomware's ability to encrypt data is a significant indicator of malicious intent.

---

**Category: CAT10 - Misuse of Resources**

**Explanation:**

The incident describes cryptocurrency mining.  The attacker is using the compromised host to generate cryptocurrency.

**Risk Level:** Low – Cryptocurrency mining is a legitimate activity, but its use of a compromised system is a potential indicator of malicious intent.

**Further Considerations:** The specific cryptocurrency being mined could be relevant for further investigation.

---

**Category: CAT11 - Third-Party Issues**

**Explanation:**

The incident describes a SaaS breach, which is a common issue with third-party providers.

**Risk Level:** Medium – A breach involving a SaaS provider raises concerns about data security and the potential for widespread exposure.

**Further Considerations:** Identifying the affected SaaS provider is crucial for mitigation.

---

**Category: CAT12 - Intrusion Attempt**

**Explanation:**

The incident describes a network scan and brute-force attempt.

**Risk Level:** Low –  A network scan is a standard activity, but the brute-force attempt raises a more serious concern.

**Further Considerations:** It might be part of a larger attack campaign.

---

**Classification Summary:**

The incident is best classified as a **CAT1 - Account Compromise** incident, strongly suggesting a sophisticated attack targeting a user account and the subsequent exploitation of a botnet.  It also contains elements of several other categories, which is why it's a multi-faceted incident requiring a thorough investigation.

Let me know if you’d like me to elaborate on any specific aspect of the classification!

prompt:
You are a cybersecurity expert specializing in incident classification.
Your task is to analyze security incidents and categorize them according to NIST guidelines.

NIST SECURITY INCIDENT CATEGORIES:

• CAT1: Account Compromise – Unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts
  Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft

• CAT2: Malware – Infection by malicious code
  Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus

• CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – Making systems unavailable
  Examples: volumetric DoS/DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood), HTTP/HTTPS attacks

• CAT4: Data Leak – Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data
  Examples: database theft, leaked credentials

• CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – Using technical flaws for attacks
  Examples: CVE exploitation, RCE, SQL injection, exposed services

• CAT6: Insider Abuse – Malicious actions by internal users
  Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage

• CAT7: Social Engineering – Deception to gain access or data
  Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud

• CAT8: Physical Incident – Impact due to unauthorized physical access
  Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in

• CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – Improper changes to systems or data
  Examples: defacement, record manipulation

• CAT10: Misuse of Resources – Unauthorized use for other purposes
  Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution

• CAT11: Third-Party Issues – Security failures by suppliers
  Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack

• CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – Unconfirmed attacks
  Examples: network scans, brute force attempts, blocked exploits

CLASSIFICATION EXAMPLES:

Example 1:
Incident: "Multiple failed SSH login attempts detected from external IP 192.168.1.100"
Category: CAT12
Explanation: Network scanning and brute force attempts represent intrusion attempts that were blocked/detected but not successful.

Example 2:
Incident: "Ransomware detected on workstation, files encrypted with .crypto extension"
Category: CAT2
Explanation: Clear malware infection with ransomware, representing malicious code that has successfully infected the system.

Example 3:
Incident: "Employee accessed and downloaded customer database without authorization"
Category: CAT6
Explanation: Internal user performing unauthorized actions, representing insider abuse of access privileges.

Para: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_f6f7086365], [EMAIL_ADDRESS_a0a85d701e]
CC: [EMAIL_ADDRESS_83824c64b2]
Assunto: Alerta: [AS 2716] servidor NTP mal configurado

Caro responsável,

Os IPs presentes no log abaixo são servidores NTP mal configurados sob
sua responsabilidade (123/udp). Estes servidores podem ser abusados
para fazer parte de ataques distribuídos de negação de serviço,
consumindo recursos da sua rede e impactando terceiros.

Lembramos que os endereços IP listados também podem ser dispositivos
de rede com funcionalidade NTP, como roteadores e CPEs (modem ou

disable monitor

restrict default kod notrap nomodify nopeer noquery

prompt:
You are a cybersecurity expert specializing in incident classification.
Your task is to analyze security incidents and categorize them according to NIST guidelines.

NIST SECURITY INCIDENT CATEGORIES:

• CAT1: Account Compromise – Unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts
  Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft

• CAT2: Malware – Infection by malicious code
  Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus

• CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – Making systems unavailable
  Examples: volumetric DoS/DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood), HTTP/HTTPS attacks

• CAT4: Data Leak – Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data
  Examples: database theft, leaked credentials

• CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – Using technical flaws for attacks
  Examples: CVE exploitation, RCE, SQL injection, exposed services

• CAT6: Insider Abuse – Malicious actions by internal users
  Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage

• CAT7: Social Engineering – Deception to gain access or data
  Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud

• CAT8: Physical Incident – Impact due to unauthorized physical access
  Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in

• CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – Improper changes to systems or data
  Examples: defacement, record manipulation

• CAT10: Misuse of Resources – Unauthorized use for other purposes
  Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution

• CAT11: Third-Party Issues – Security failures by suppliers
  Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack

• CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – Unconfirmed attacks
  Examples: network scans, brute force attempts, blocked exploits

CLASSIFICATION EXAMPLES:

Example 1:
Incident: "Multiple failed SSH login attempts detected from external IP 192.168.1.100"
Category: CAT12
Explanation: Network scanning and brute force attempts represent intrusion attempts that were blocked/detected but not successful.

Example 2:
Incident: "Ransomware detected on workstation, files encrypted with .crypto extension"
Category: CAT2
Explanation: Clear malware infection with ransomware, representing malicious code that has successfully infected the system.

Example 3:
Incident: "Employee accessed and downloaded customer database without authorization"
Category: CAT6
Explanation: Internal user performing unauthorized actions, representing insider abuse of access privileges.

Okay, let's classify this incident based on the NIST Cybersecurity Incident Categories.

**Classification:**

**Category: CAT2 - Malware - Ransomware Detected on Workstation**

**Explanation:**

The incident details a ransomware infection detected on a workstation (`[IP_ADDRESS_b29a075d57]`). The report explicitly states "Ransomware detected on workstation, files encrypted with .crypto extension".  This strongly indicates malware infection, which is the core of the malware category. The report also confirms that the user attempted to connect to a command-line interface (SSH) to attempt to access the system. This behavior is indicative of an active malicious attack.

**Key Indicators Supporting the Category:**

*   **Ransomware:** The report clearly identifies ransomware as the threat.
*   **Workstation Infection:**  The incident focuses on a single workstation, suggesting an attempt to encrypt files and potentially compromise the entire system.
*   **.crypto extension:** This is a common indicator of ransomware, used to encrypt files with a unique signature.
*   **SSH Attempt:** The attempted connection to the command line reveals the attacker was actively trying to gain access to the system.

**Why not other categories?**

*   **CAT1 - Account Compromise:** While the user attempted SSH login, this isn't the primary focus of the incident. It's a symptom of the broader attack.
*   **CAT3 - Denial of Service:** The ransomware doesn't immediately cause a denial-of-service situation, though potential disruption of services could be a consequence.
*   **CAT4 - Data Leak:**  The ransomware is encrypted and the focus is on data, not leaking data.
*   **CAT5 - Vulnerability Exploitation:**  The incident doesn't directly involve exploiting a vulnerability.
*   **CAT6 - Insider Abuse:** The incident doesn't reveal information on any malicious actions by internal users.
*   **CAT7 - Social Engineering:** There is no evidence of social engineering involved.
*   **CAT8 - Physical Incident:** There is no physical evidence of any kind.
*   **CAT9 - Unauthorized Modification:**  The ransomware is actively modifying files, not altering configurations.
*   **CAT10 - Misuse of Resources:** The incident doesn’t involve using resources for any other purpose.

**Recommendation:**

Immediate investigation is crucial to determine:

1.  **Type of Ransomware:** Identify the specific ransomware variant to determine the best response.
2.  **System Impact:** Assess the extent of the infection on the workstation.
3.  **System Recovery:** Implement remediation steps to restore the system to a clean state.
4.  **Investigation:** Determine the root cause of the infection to prevent future occurrences.

* O que é o serviço SNMP (161/udp)?

O SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) é um protocolo de rede
  utilizado para gerenciamento e diagnóstico de dispositivos de redes.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
  ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
  porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
  servidor com SNMP retorna uma resposta muito maior que a requisição.

* Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O serviço SNMP pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros,
  envolvendo sua rede em ataques a outras organizações, além de
  implicar em um consumo de banda maior.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
  para este e outros ataques DDoS podem ser econtradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

* Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Se o SNMP não for utilizado na sua rede desabilite o serviço no seu
  dispositivo. Se o recurso for utilizado na rede local, configure-o
  de modo que esteja disponível apenas para a rede local.

Evite utilizar comunidades public e se possível utilize autenticação
  quando disponível.

* Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
  SNMP para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
    [URL_f1b488990d]

* Como o [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] sabe que este é um dispositivo vulnerável?

O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está recebendo notificações com listas de dispositivos
  que usam SNMP que possivelmente estão sendo abusados e utilizados em
  ataques distribuídos de negação de serviços (DDoS).  O [ORGANIZATION_54947c67d4] está
  notificando os responsáveis pelos dispositivos brasileiros presentes
  nestas listas.

* Como posso ter certeza que resolvi o problema?

Você pode verificar seu dispositivo atravás dos seguintes comandos:
  (preferencialmente execute-os a partir da Internet, ou seja, fora de
  uma rede interna que tenha permissão de acesso ao dispositivo).

$ snmpget -v 2c -c public IP_SNMP iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

ou

$ snmpctl snmp get IP_SNMP oid iso.[IP_ADDRESS_38d1648825].[IP_ADDRESS_5156ba048d]

Onde IP_SNMP é o IP do dispositivo usando SNMP a ser testad

**Incident:**  **CAT12 – Intrusion Attempt – Network Scanning & Brute Force**

**Explanation:**

* **Severity:** While not explicitly stated, the nature of the attack (brute force) elevates the severity. It could be a precursor to further malicious activity.
* **NIST Alignment:**  This aligns with the “Misuse of Resources” category – unauthorized use of network resources for malicious purposes.

* **CAT3 – Denial of Service (Potential):** While not directly stated, the blocked SSH attempts *could* be part of a larger attack aimed at disrupting network services.  It would need further investigation to confirm this.

**Recommendations (Based on the Incident):**

1. O que é o serviço Portmap (111/udp)?

O serviço Portmap, também chamado de Portmapper ou rpcbind, é
   utilizado para mapear serviços RPC na rede, como NIS e NFS. Esse
   serviço geralmente é utilizado por sistemas Unix, especialmente para
   compartilhamento de arquivos, além de outros serviços.

Por se tratar de um serviço geralmente utilizado apenas dentro de
   redes locais, é muito provável que não exista necessidade do serviço
   Portmap estar exposto à Internet.

Caso esteja acessível a toda a Internet via UDP, esse serviço pode
   ser explorado para ataques DDoS que usem amplificação. Isto ocorre
   porque o atacante envia uma requisição forjando o IP da vítima e o
   servidor com Portmap retorna uma resposta muito maior que a
   requisição.

2. Por que devo me preocupar com isso?

O Portmap pode ser abusado para causar danos a terceiros, envolvendo
   sua rede em ataques a outras organizações e implicando em um consumo
   de banda maior. Além dessas implicações, esse serviço pode revelar
   informações sensíveis sobre sua rede e seus dados armazenados.

Informações adicionais sobre como evitar que sua rede seja abusada
   para ataques DDoS podem ser encontradas aqui:

[URL_eebddb46c5]

3. Como faço para corrigir o problema?

Configure o serviço Portmap de forma que ele seja acessível somente
   aos dispositivos de sua rede, que utilizem esse serviço, ou que ele
   seja acessível apenas via TCP. Caso o serviço Portmap seja
   desnecessário nesse servidor, recomendamos que ele seja desativado.

4. Onde posso obter informações adicionais sobre o abuso do protocolo
   Portmap para ataques DDoS?

- UDP-Based Amplification Attacks
     [URL_f1b488990d]

- Openly accessible Portmapper services
     [URL_5f26128084]

You are a cybersecurity expert specializing in incident classification.

NIST SECURITY INCIDENT CATEGORIES:

• CAT1: Account Compromise – Unauthorized access to user or administrator accounts
  Examples: credential phishing, SSH brute force, OAuth token theft

• CAT2: Malware – Infection by malicious code
  Examples: ransomware, Trojan horse, macro virus

• CAT3: Denial of Service Attack – Making systems unavailable
  Examples: volumetric DoS/DDoS (UDP flood, SYN flood), HTTP/HTTPS attacks

• CAT4: Data Leak – Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data
  Examples: database theft, leaked credentials

• CAT5: Vulnerability Exploitation – Using technical flaws for attacks
  Examples: CVE exploitation, RCE, SQL injection, exposed services

• CAT6: Insider Abuse – Malicious actions by internal users
  Examples: copying confidential data, sabotage

• CAT7: Social Engineering – Deception to gain access or data
  Examples: phishing, vishing, CEO fraud

• CAT8: Physical Incident – Impact due to unauthorized physical access
  Examples: laptop theft, data center break-in

• CAT9: Unauthorized Modification – Improper changes to systems or data
  Examples: defacement, record manipulation

• CAT10: Misuse of Resources – Unauthorized use for other purposes
  Examples: cryptocurrency mining, malware distribution

• CAT11: Third-Party Issues – Security failures by suppliers
  Examples: SaaS breach, supply chain attack

• CAT12: Intrusion Attempt – Unconfirmed attacks
  Examples: network scans, brute force attempts, blocked exploits

The fact that the incident was triggered by a "report from CERT.br" indicates a potential security alert or threat detection system is active. The attempted actions are specifically targeting the network’s resources by attempting to exploit vulnerabilities through SNMP. * **CAT12 –  Network Attack:** The event has the potential to launch a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack by flooding the network.


**Further Considerations (Beyond the Provided Information):**
